entity1.name: Climate change
entity1.description: The variations in the amount of available water due to factors like climate change, population growth, or land use changes.;;;A significant and lasting change in the statistical distribution of weather patterns over periods ranging from decades to millions of years.;;;Long-term alteration in statistical distribution of weather patterns over periods ranging from decades to millions of years, often attributed to human activities such as deforestation and burning fossil fuels.;;;A significant variation in the Earth's global climate patterns over time, often attributed to human activities such as deforestation and burning fossil fuels.;;;Prolonged periods of abnormally low rainfall leading to water shortages and affecting agriculture and ecosystems.;;;The average temperature of the Earth's atmosphere, which is increasing due to human activities and natural processes.;;;The amount of water that is accessible for use by humans, animals, and plants, including surface water, groundwater, and desalinated seawater.;;;Natural occurrences that are severe and unusual, such as hurricanes, floods, or droughts.;;;Patterns of rainfall or other forms of water falling from the sky, which can vary over time and space.;;;Long-term alterations in temperature, precipitation, wind patterns, and other elements of weather that occur over several decades or longer due to natural processes or human activities.;;;A significant variation of climate conditions over time, often caused by human activities such as burning fossil fuels, deforestation, and industrial processes, leading to global warming and other environmental impacts.;;;A measure of the degree of hotness or coldness in the environment, often used to describe weather conditions.;;;A situation where there is not enough water to meet the needs of people or ecosystems in a region.;;;The specific atmospheric and environmental conditions that affect agricultural practices and outcomes.;;;An increase in the ambient temperature of an environment.;;;An overflow of water that submerges land which is usually dry, often causing damage to property and infrastructure.;;;Alterations in long-term weather patterns that can affect ecosystems, agriculture, and human activities.

entity2.name: planet
entity2.description: The Earth, the third planet from the Sun and the only known celestial body to support life.
entity2.chunkid: The Impact of Climate Change on Global Agriculture1

entity3.name: human life
entity3.description: The condition or state of a human being; encompasses all aspects of existence including biological, social, and cultural dimensions.;;;The means of securing the basic necessities of life, including food, water, shelter, income, and health care.
entity3.chunkid: The Impact of Climate Change on Global Agriculture22;;;The Impact of Climate Change on Global Agriculture1

entity4.name: global agriculture
entity4.description: The worldwide cultivation of plants and rearing of animals for food, fiber, biofuel, medicinal, and other products used to sustain human life.;;;Crops that have been developed to withstand periods of low water availability, helping farmers maintain productivity during droughts.;;;Plants grown for food, fiber, biofuel, or other uses, which are essential to human and animal nutrition.;;;The amount of crop produced per unit area, typically measured in weight or volume.;;;The process of growing crops for food, fiber, or other uses.;;;The practice of cultivating the land or raising stock.;;;Plants grown in significant quantities to be harvested as food, animal feed, or other uses.;;;The science, art, and business of cultivating plants and livestock.;;;The practice of cultivating the soil, producing crops, and raising livestock for food, fiber, biofuel, and other products necessary to sustain life.;;;Plants grown for food or other uses in agriculture.;;;The period during which conditions are suitable for plant growth, typically determined by temperature and precipitation patterns.;;;A set of agricultural methods designed to protect the environment, public health, human communities, and animal welfare.;;;A method of crop and livestock production that avoids or largely excludes the use of synthetic fertilizers, pesticides, growth regulators, and livestock feed additives.;;;The practice of cultivating land for growing crops and raising livestock, which is a fundamental sector in the global economy.;;;Agricultural practices that are environmentally friendly and economically viable, aimed at meeting the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs.;;;The specific times of the year when crops are planted and harvested, which can vary based on climate and crop type.;;;The worldwide industry involved in the cultivation of plants, animals, and other life forms for food, fiber, biofuel, and other products used to sustain human life.;;;The process of growing crops on a large scale for commercial or subsistence purposes.;;;A set of methods and techniques used in farming that aim to protect the environment, public health, human communities, and animal welfare.;;;A set of methods and techniques used in farming that aim to meet human food and fiber needs while protecting natural resources and the environment.;;;A set of strategies and methods aimed at ensuring the long-term availability and quality of water resources.

entity8.name: Food security
entity8.description: The state of having reliable access to a sufficient quantity of affordable, nutritious food.;;;A condition related to the supply of food, and people's access to it. It exists when all people at all times have physical, social, and economic access to sufficient, safe, and nutritious food.;;;The condition where all people have reliable access to sufficient quantities of affordable, nutritious food that meets their dietary needs and preferences for an active and healthy life.
entity8.chunkid: The Impact of Climate Change on Global Agriculture22;;;The Impact of Climate Change on Global Agriculture24;;;The Impact of Climate Change on Global Agriculture2

entity57.name: agroforestry
entity57.description: An integrated approach that combines trees with crops or livestock on the same piece of land to create more diverse, productive, profitable, healthy, and sustainable land-use systems.

entity58.name: crop rotation
entity58.description: A farming technique where different types of crops are grown in the same area across a sequence of seasons to improve soil health, optimize nutrients in the soil, and combat pests and diseases.

entity60.name: soil health
